title: Kirchhoff loop - rank V1 V2 V3 in two circuits

content.question: In the two circuits shown in the figure, the two batteries have the same <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math> and each resistor has a resistance of either <math alttext="the fraction R over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> or <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> as indicated. The potential differences across three of the resistors are indicated as well. Taking the three potential difference values to all be positive quantities, which of the following correctly compares <math alttext="delta V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta V sub 1, equals delta V sub 2, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1, is greater than delta V sub 2, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1, equals delta V sub 3, which is greater than delta V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1, is greater than delta V sub 3, which is greater than delta V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="delta V sub 1, is greater than delta V sub 2, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
